message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The generalizability crisis
Paper Abstract: Abstract Most theories and hypotheses in psychology are verbal in nature, yet their evaluation overwhelmingly relies on inferential statistical procedures. The validity of the move from qualitative to quantitative analysis depends on the verbal and statistical expressions of a hypothesis being closely aligned – that is, that the two must refer to roughly the same set of hypothetical observations. Here, I argue that many applications of statistical inference in psychology fail to meet this basic condition. Focusing on the most widely used class of model in psychology – the linear mixed model – I explore the consequences of failing to statistically operationalize verbal hypotheses in a way that respects researchers' actual generalization intentions. I demonstrate that although the “random effect” formalism is used pervasively in psychology to model intersubject variability, few researchers accord the same treatment to other variables they clearly intend to generalize over (e.g., stimuli, tasks, or research sites). The under-specification of random effects imposes far stronger constraints on the generalizability of results than most researchers appreciate. Ignoring these constraints can dramatically inflate false-positive rates, and often leads researchers to draw sweeping verbal generalizations that lack a meaningful connection to the statistical quantities they are putatively based on. I argue that failure to take the alignment between verbal and statistical expressions seriously lies at the heart of many of psychology's ongoing problems (e.g., the replication crisis), and conclude with a discussion of several potential avenues for improvement.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the random effects model:

## Definition

A random effects model, also called a variance components model, is a statistical model where the model effects are random variables.(no content)It is a kind of hierarchical linear model, which assumes that the data being analysed are drawn from a hierarchy of different populations whose differences relate to that hierarchy.

## Key Characteristics

A random effects model is a special case of a mixed model.(no content)Random effect models assist in controlling for unobserved heterogeneity when the heterogeneity is constant over time and not correlated with independent variables.

## Applications and Benefits

Random effects introduce statistical variability at different levels of the data hierarchy.(no content)Mixed models properly account for nest structures/hierarchical data structures where observations are influenced by their nested associations.(no content)If the random effects assumption holds, the random effects estimator is more efficient than the fixed effects model.

## Real-World Examples

Random effects models used in practice include the Bühlmann model of insurance contracts and the Fay-Herriot model used for small area estimation.

The random effects model is particularly useful for analyzing grouped or hierarchical data, such as students nested within schools or measurements taken over time on the same subjects.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the random effects model:

## Definition

A random effects model, also called a variance components model, is a statistical model where the model effects are random variables.(no content)It is a kind of hierarchical linear model, which assumes that the data being analysed are drawn from a hierarchy of different populations whose differences relate to that hierarchy.

## Key Characteristics

A random effects model is a special case of a mixed model.(no content)Random effect models assist in controlling for unobserved heterogeneity when the heterogeneity is constant over time and not correlated with independent variables.

## Applications and Benefits

Random effects introduce statistical variability at different levels of the data hierarchy.(no content)Mixed models properly account for nest structures/hierarchical data structures where observations are influenced by their nested associations.(no content)If the random effects assumption holds, the random effects estimator is more efficient than the fixed effects model.

## Real-World Examples

Random effects models used in practice include the Bühlmann model of insurance contracts and the Fay-Herriot model used for small area estimation.

The random effects model is particularly useful for analyzing grouped or hierarchical data, such as students nested within schools or measurements taken over time on the same subjects.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **statistical inference**:

## Definition

Statistical inference makes propositions about a population, using data drawn from the population with some form of sampling.(no content)Inferential statistical analysis infers properties of a population, for example by testing hypotheses and deriving estimates.

## Key Characteristics

It is assumed that the observed data set is sampled from a larger population.(no content)Statistical inference consists of (first) selecting a statistical model of the process that generates the data and (second) deducing propositions from the model.(no content)Inferential statistics can be contrasted with descriptive statistics. Descriptive statistics is solely concerned with properties of the observed data, and it does not rest on the assumption that the data come from a larger population.

## Main Approaches

There are two major frameworks for statistical inference:

1. **Frequentist Inference**: Frequentist inference is a type of statistical inference based in frequentist probability, which treats "probability" in equivalent terms to "frequency" and draws conclusions from sample-data by means of emphasizing the frequency or proportion of findings in the data.

2. **Bayesian Inference**: Fundamentally, Bayesian inference uses a prior distribution to estimate posterior probabilities.

## Common Methods

A statistical hypothesis test is a method of statistical inference used to decide whether the data provide sufficient evidence to reject a particular hypothesis.

I've completed a web search for "linear mixed model". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Linear mixed models (LMMs) are statistical models that incorporate fixed and random effects to accurately represent non-independent data structures.(no content)LMM is an alternative to analysis of variance.

## When to Use

ANOVA assumes the statistical independence of observations within each group, however, this assumption may not hold in non-independent data, such as multilevel/hierarchical, longitudinal, or correlated datasets.(no content)They are particularly useful in settings where repeated measurements are made on the same statistical units (see also longitudinal study), or where measurements are made on clusters of related statistical units.

## Components

A key component of the mixed model is the incorporation of random effects with the fixed effect. Fixed effects are often fitted to represent the underlying model.(no content)Random effects introduce statistical variability at different levels of the data hierarchy. These account for the unmeasured sources of variance that affect certain groups in the data.

## Advantages

Mixed models are often preferred over traditional analysis of variance regression models because they don't rely on the independent observations assumption. Further, they have their flexibility in dealing with missing values and uneven spacing of repeated measurements.

## Applications

Mixed models are applied in many disciplines where multiple correlated measurements are made on each unit of interest. They are prominently used in research involving human and animal subjects in fields ranging from genetics to marketing, and have also been used in baseball and industrial statistics.

Links: [{"title":"Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Reproducibility Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility_Project"},{"title":"Reproducibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility"},{"title":"HARKing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HARKing"},{"title":"Replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication"},{"title":"Talk:Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Social psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology"},{"title":"Norbert Schwarz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norbert_Schwarz"},{"title":"Replication (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_(computing)"},{"title":"Replication (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_(statistics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the replication crisis:

## What is the Replication Crisis?

The replication crisis, also known as the reproducibility or replicability crisis, refers to widespread failures to reproduce published scientific results.(no content)Because the reproducibility of empirical results is the cornerstone of the scientific method, such failures undermine the credibility of theories and challenge substantial parts of scientific knowledge.

## Scope and Affected Fields

Psychology and medicine have been focal points for replication efforts, with researchers systematically reexamining classic studies to verify their reliability and, when failures emerge, to identify the underlying causes. However, data strongly indicate that other natural and social sciences are also affected.

## Origins and Timeline

The phrase "replication crisis" was coined in the early 2010s as part of a growing awareness of the problem.(no content)Key precursors to the crisis included social priming failures: In the early 2010s, two direct replication attempts failed to reproduce results from social psychologist John Bargh's much-cited "elderly-walking" study (originally published in 1996).

## Contributing Factors

Bishop described HARKing as one of "the four horsemen of the reproducibility apocalypse," with publication bias, low statistical power, and p-hacking being the other three. Additionally, researchers showed in a 2006 study that 73% of authors did not respond with their data, and in a 2015 follow-up study, 62% of contacted authors of papers in APA journals did not share their data upon request.

## Response to the Crisis

Considerations of causes and remedies have given rise to a new scientific discipline known as metascience, which uses methods of empirical research to examine empirical research practice.

Links: [{"title":"Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Reproducibility Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility_Project"},{"title":"Reproducibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility"},{"title":"HARKing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HARKing"},{"title":"Replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication"},{"title":"Talk:Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Social psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology"},{"title":"Norbert Schwarz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norbert_Schwarz"},{"title":"Replication (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_(computing)"},{"title":"Replication (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_(statistics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the replication crisis:

## What is the Replication Crisis?

The replication crisis, also known as the reproducibility or replicability crisis, refers to widespread failures to reproduce published scientific results.(no content)Because the reproducibility of empirical results is the cornerstone of the scientific method, such failures undermine the credibility of theories and challenge substantial parts of scientific knowledge.

## Scope and Affected Fields

Psychology and medicine have been focal points for replication efforts, with researchers systematically reexamining classic studies to verify their reliability and, when failures emerge, to identify the underlying causes. However, data strongly indicate that other natural and social sciences are also affected.

## Origins and Timeline

The phrase "replication crisis" was coined in the early 2010s as part of a growing awareness of the problem.(no content)Key precursors to the crisis included social priming failures: In the early 2010s, two direct replication attempts failed to reproduce results from social psychologist John Bargh's much-cited "elderly-walking" study (originally published in 1996).

## Contributing Factors

Bishop described HARKing as one of "the four horsemen of the reproducibility apocalypse," with publication bias, low statistical power, and p-hacking being the other three. Additionally, researchers showed in a 2006 study that 73% of authors did not respond with their data, and in a 2015 follow-up study, 62% of contacted authors of papers in APA journals did not share their data upon request.

## Response to the Crisis

Considerations of causes and remedies have given rise to a new scientific discipline known as metascience, which uses methods of empirical research to examine empirical research practice.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of psychology:

## Definition and Scope

Psychology is the scientific study of behavior and mind.(no content)Its subject matter includes the behavior of humans and nonhumans, both conscious and unconscious phenomena, and mental processes such as thoughts, feelings, and motives.(no content)Psychology is an academic discipline of immense scope, crossing the boundaries between the natural and social sciences.

## Key Areas of Study

Psychologists are involved in research on perception, cognition, attention, emotion, intelligence, subjective experiences, motivation, brain functioning, and personality.(no content)Psychologists' interests extend to interpersonal relationships, psychological resilience, family resilience, and other areas within social psychology.

## Professional Practice

Many psychologists are involved in some kind of therapeutic role, practicing psychotherapy in clinical, counseling, or school settings, while other psychologists conduct scientific research on a wide range of topics related to mental processes and behavior.

## Key Subdisciplines

Several major areas within psychology include:
- **Clinical Psychology**: An integration of human science, behavioral science, theory, and clinical knowledge aimed at understanding, preventing, and relieving psychological distress or dysfunction as well as promoting well-being and personal growth.
- **Developmental Psychology**: The scientific study of how and why humans grow, change, and adapt across the course of their lives.
- **Social Psychology**: The methodical study of how thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed all tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes improvements to how researchers should operationalize statistical hypotheses and specify random effects in linear mixed models.

**Extracted Triples (5 total):**

1. **Mixed model** (method) - `uses` - Linear mixed models are the primary focus of the paper's critique about random effect specification in psychology research.

2. **Statistical inference** (method) - `uses` - The paper argues that evaluation of psychological hypotheses relies overwhelmingly on inferential statistical procedures.

3. **Random effects model** (method) - `proposes` - The paper proposes better specification and alignment of random effects to match researchers' actual generalization intentions.

4. **Psychology** (task) - `uses` - Psychology is the primary domain where the paper identifies problems with statistical operationalization of verbal hypotheses.

5. **Replication crisis** (concept) - `uses` - The paper argues that failure to align verbal and statistical expressions lies at the heart of psychology's replication crisis.

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully. The JSON file meets all requirements with proper Wikipedia URLs, relevant relations, and entity classifications.
